KCSC-KMS Students Earn Top 10 Finish
Knox Middle School students recently placed eighth in the nation in the Mathspace Growth Challenge. Every Grade 6 and Grade 7 student participated in the six-week challenge, scoring a total of 471,773 points.

KMS students competed against more than 40,000 students in 250 schools across 36 states. Knox is the only Indiana school to place in the top 20 schools in the nation.

Mathspace is an adaptive learning program that provides students immediate feedback for their responses. One KMS student completed more than 6,000 questions for the national competition.

Pictured here are five students who represented KMS at the most recent school board Spotlight on Success. These students are (left to right) Garin Phipps, Noah Bolen, Lucas Skelly, Abrianna Austin, and Emma Gillard.

Congratulations to all of the students and to their teachers, Mrs. Amber Clemons (who organized the competition), Ms. Jennifer Lichtle, Mr. David Miller, Ms. Kaitlin Miller, and Mrs. Heather Reese.

KCSC-Coach Hendryx to Receive Special Award
KCSC Head Football Coach John Hendryx will be awarded the Semper Fi Coach Award today in Indianapolis. The U.S. Marine Corps and Glazier Clinics selected Coach Hendryx for this award based on his modeling of the Marine Corps leadership values of Honor, Courage, and Commitment.

Coach Hendryx, a veteran football coach of 31 years, says he is "very humbled" by his selection for this award, an award given to only one coach in each state. He notes that he has been "very blessed in my coaching career to have had great assistant coaches, and kids that have been willing to work hard and understand that the lessons that can be learned by participating are far greater than the winning and losing."

Congratulations to Coach Hendryx for this prestigious award.

Congratulations to Coach Hendryx for this prestigious award.

KCSC-It All Adds Up
Students in Mrs. Jamie Shireman's Knox Elementary class took time recently to share some of their math problem-solving strategies. Pictured here is one second grader who explained to his classmates the mental math strategy he used to find the total cost for three pieces of candy that cost 15, 10, and 25 cents. As he said, you just add up the tens place value for each item, then add the two fives that remain to make another ten, and it all comes to 50 cents.

The other student pictured here proudly displayed the extra math work he has been doing in his free time at home. He plans to continue working on all four mathematical operations.

The entire class then recited their math motto, "I will not accept IDK on DOK problems!" In other words, they will not give an I don't know (IDK) answer to any depth of knowledge (DOK) math problems presented to them.

KCSC-It's Not About the Duct Tape
Knox High School students in Ms. Jacqueline Zaiko's Aquatics classes were recently challenged to build a boat made only of cardboard and duct tape. The goal was for the boat to "live" through one trip down and back the length of the pool.

Pictured here are the crew members of Noah's Ark and No Name. The students say it took them about four hours and five rolls of duct tape to make their creations.

Even though 60% of the boats will sink shortly after leaving the dock, the two crafts in this post met the goal. They did, however, sink before reaching the record of sailing 10 lengths of the pool set last year.

The student objective for this assignment was to demonstrate how to work as a group to accomplish a goal. The objective correlates to the teamwork benchmark of using effective collaboration and cooperation skills outlined in the Indiana Employability Skills created by the Indiana Department of Workforce Development.
